title-group.article-title: A new time-domain method for calculation of basic electric values in public distribution networks

author-notes.corresp: Predrag B Petrović, Technical Faculty Cacak, Svetog Save 65, Cacak, 32000, Serbia. Email: predragp@tfc.kg.ac.rs

abstract.p: The paper proposes a practical new algorithm for calculation of electrical active power and root mean square value of current and voltage signals using a windowing technique by reducing the weight of samples at the endpoints of sampling interval. The proposed method offers a significant improvement in computational efficiency with a low numerical error. The calculation of observed values was realized by summation of samples of instantaneous power in a time domain, without the need for synchronization. The suggested algorithm was simulated and experimentally tested. The errors related to the signal processing, and errors bound were investigated and provided. A processing precision of 0.05% was achieved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As is well known, during the past few years, the major part of electrical loads in common power systems has become non-linear or parametric (time varying); this is because of the proliferation among industrial, commercial and residential customers of power-electronic equipment, such as adjustable-speed drives, controlled rectifiers, cycloconverters, electronically ballasted lamps, arc and induction furnaces, and clusters of personal computers. Such loads may create a host of disturbances to the utility and to other customers’ equipment. For these very reasons, it is important to develop measuring systems capable of performing the calculation of basic AC values in the presence of the higher harmonic components, within the processed voltage and current signals (Bucci and Landi, 1999; Carbone and Petri, 2000; Jiekang et al., 2005; Routray et al., 2002).

Power components such as active, reactive, distortion, non-active and apparent powers are defined by the IEEE Standard 1459-2000 (2000) using fast Fourier transforms (FFT). For the case of stationary wave forms, the FFT can provide accurate results; however, for the case of non-stationary waveforms, the FFT introduces large errors due to spectral leakage and picket fence phenomena (Bollen and Gu, 2006). The wavelet transform, which is considered a time-frequency transform, is capable of handling and accurately representing non-stationary waveforms in many applications in different disciplines (Croes et al., 2004; Hamid et al., 2002). The power of the wavelet stems from the fact that it can provide variable frequency resolution while preserving time information. This is an important requirement for the analysis and measurement of the non-stationary waveforms that possess time-variant characteristics, and this is lost when using the FFT.

The conventional algorithms for the measurement of active power and effective values of voltage and current employ integration or summation over an abruptly limited time interval (Arpaia et al., 1996; Clarke and Stockton, 1982; Germer, 2001; Petrovic, 2008; Petrovic and Stevanovic, 2009; Pogliano, 2001; Ramm et al., 1999). Some of these methods (Germer, 2001; Pogliano, 2001; Ramm et al., 1999) can offer exceptionally high precision in the calculation of basic electrical values, but only after conducting a complex calibration procedure and engaging the high processor’s power. Consequently, they operate correctly at a periodic input signal only. The voltage and current waveforms of the power network, however, are not strictly periodic, due to their non-harmonic components and stochastic variation. It is for this reason and in order to preserve the high performances of such algorithms that it is necessary to analyse the possible sources of errors in the determination of the integration interval (Langella and Testa, 2011), as well as to introduce special estimation procedures (Udrea and Vizireanu, 2008; Vizireanu, 2009, 2011; Vizireanu and Halunga, 2011, 2012), all of which makes their structure additionally complex. Because of this, the outputs of these algorithms often do not represent the input’s instantaneous value, but the input observed over a certain period. Based on estimated signal parameters (Udrea and Vizireanu, 2008; Vizireanu, 2009, 2011; Vizireanu and Halunga, 2011, 2012), we can obtain the root mean square (RMS) value of the processed signals, and realize precise measurements of other important electrical values such as power and energy.

This paper offers a new approach to processing analogue signals (most AC that can be represented in the form of Fourier series, such as AC signals in public distribution networks), within a twice-shorter time interval, compared with other methods in standard use. It is primarily directed towards determining the value of the active power of the signals, or the effective value (RMS) of the signal being processed, without a need for synchronization. The method suggested here does not depend on complex hardware or intensive numerical calculations, which makes its practical realization very inexpensive, and it does not require any special estimation procedure that would need a subsequent refining of the obtained results.

sec.p: As has been defined by Equation (6), the number of ZCs of the voltage signal is evaluated by a sign-test of consecutive samples. This type of approach is radically different from the methods described previously (Hindersah et al., 2011; Martens et al., 2008; Yazici and Ozdemir, 2011), which are based on the use of either phase locked loop (PLL), or filtering of the harmonics and after-sampling, or sampling of the whole signal, filtering the harmonics and post-processing etc., which are more complicated than the threshold crossing technique proposed in this paper.

In order to increase the anti-noise capability, a 2n-length window of data can be used. A ZC is determined to be included in the window only when n consecutive samples have positive signs and n consecutive samples have negative signs. By taking n=3 … 5, the erroneous ZC brought by ransom noise could be effectively reduced. After the ZC is detected, the ZC position on the time-axis can be located by linear interpolation with two consecutive samples that have different signs. A security condition is also added to exclude erroneous ZC. That is, if the interval between two ZC is significantly different from the previous interval, the newly detected ZC will be deemed invalid and the previous frequency result will be used instead. With this simple logic, the derived frequency accuracy is already sufficiently good. The problem of determining the frequency of the processed signal is a major issue in measuring AC signals (Jiekang et al., 2005; Kuseljević, 2010). In order to be realized, all of them require a highly complex mathematical apparatus and a large amount of processing time. The idea of the authors, on the other hand, was to develop a simpler algorithm of a low numerical complexity, capable of offering enough precision in determining the frequency of the processed signals. This was confirmed by the results of the checks that were performed on the suggested algorithm.

From (12), it follows that the estimated error depends on sampling frequency and signal period. The proposed method is immune to signal-frequency changes at high sampling frequencies. At low sampling frequencies, the fS trapezium method error is strongly dependent on signal frequency f.

Synchronization error could be minimized by choosing the sampling frequency fS, which is not an integer multiple of signal frequency f. In this way, the average jitter in the calculation of integral boundaries will have a tendency to become close to zero. The synchronization error is negligible to trapezium method error.

To make the realization easier, it is most appropriate to choose t1=0 in Equation (3). If sampling frequency is high enough, the outermost parts of integral, which are near the integral boundaries, are very small, and their contributions are negligible. Therefore, there is no need for their accurate calculation (the amount of computation required by proposed method (9) could be decreased by increasing the sampling frequency). The proposed method is very appropriate for hardware realization in integrated technology (in the form of IC power meter) due to the simple process of computation. The method does not need synchronization.

In order to calculate the RMS value of the input signal, it is necessary to multiply the signal sample by itself. In the end, what remains to be done is to calculate the square root of the calculated mean value of the signal’s square. This represents the definition formula with which to calculate the RMS signal value. The time needed to reach the required value (RMS, active power) is slightly longer than the half-period of the signal that is being processed, so that, in a classic-type energy system, it is slightly longer than 10 ms (or 8.33 ms for a network operating at a frequency of 60 Hz), which is considerably less than when other methods are used (Novotny and Sedlacek, 2008; Pogliano et al., 2009). If the RMS value is obtained by digital processing of a sequence of signal samples, both the uncertainty and the bias of the measured value depend on the algorithm used. Since in practice signal sampling is usually non-coherent, leakage occurs in the signal discrete Fourier transform (DFT) spectrum and the definition of the RMS of periodic signal in time domain is violated. The proposed algorithm is capable of overcoming these limitations, yielding a high level of precision in the calculation.

The added adaptivity of the proposed algorithm could be achieved by increasing the number of samples of the processed voltage and current signals (by increasing the frequency of sampling fS) from one measuring to another, in a continuous time sequence. In this way, it would be possible to improve the precision in the calculation of the active power. This would, however, also make the practical realization more complex – a disadvantage that the authors wanted to avoid in the proposed solution. It is also possible to refer the process of collecting the samples of voltage and current to a random moment (rather than fixing it as t1=0, as it has been done in the proposed algorithm), whereupon the processing can be done within a time interval that is referred in relation to the detected ZCs of the voltage signal. Although this approach enables additional degree of freedom, this modification also entails additional complexity of the proposed solution, so the final decision was to abandon this addition.

sec.title: Simulation and experimental verification of the proposed algorithm
sec.p: Additional testing of the proposed algorithm was carried out by simulation in the program package Matlab and Simulink (version R2010b) (Figure 1). Since measurement is corrupted by noise, the processing is an estimation task, i.e. the processed signals may vary, depending on the actual noise record. We investigated the issue of noise and jitter on the suggested method of processing. The presence of the noise and jitter causes false detection of voltage ZC moments, giving an incorrect calculation of active power (incorrect determination of integral boundaries). Apart from this, an error occurs in determining the value of the samples of the processed signal. This error appears as a result of the imprecision in determining the time moment at which sampling is done, as well as a result of the error introduced by the real ADC.

caption.p: Simulink model of the circuit for the realization of proposed algorithm.

sec.p: Since the suggested algorithm is practically based on the standard hardware components with which the sampling of the processed signals is done, the model that was used in simulation was the system shown in Figure 1. A sigma-delta ADC with corresponding circuit for S/H was used to perform the conversion (Hoseini et al., 2005). The precision in determining the samples of the voltage and current signal has a decisive effect on the accuracy of calculation of the active power and the RMS value, so that the ADC is simulated, taking into consideration all of the non-ideal factors that accompany a conversion process of this kind.

The input signals are formed as a super-position of harmonic components within the ‘multi-harmonic input signal’ blocks. As shown in Figure 1, noise signals were superposed on the processed voltage and current signals, which provides a simulation of the possible fluctuations and transient disturbance, so that the simulation is additionally likened to the real situation. In this way, the voltage and current signals are not constant but vary randomly around the nominal value.

Since the presence of the noise and jitter causes false detection of signal ZC moments, there is a separate model that simulates their impact on the voltage and current signals that is processed according to the proposed algorithm. All Taylor expansions of jitter are biased (Coakley et al., 2003); therefore, the correct way to include jitter is to include a variable delay in the signal path. The model by which the jitter presence is simulated is made of the pulse generator and random number, whose outputs are taken to the circuit with the variable transport delay. Figure 1 shows the addition of the white Gauss noise to the complex periodic signal. In the original toolbox, all the possible noise sources (mainly the contributions of the operational amplifiers and of the voltage references) were supposed to be white.

In order to have a highly accurate simulation of the conversion circuit, a sigma-delta ADC model described in Hoseini et al. (2005) was used (the effective resolution of the ADC during the simulation was 16 bit, and sampling rate fS=100.7 kHz). During the simulation, the value of jitter was 1 ns (standard deviation Δτ). In the course of the simulation conducted in this way, the output PSD of the ideal, thermal noise affected and clock jitter affected was in the range of −80 to −150 dB for the signal-to-noise distortion ratio (SNDR) ranged between 55 and 76 dB. A quantizer circuit is introduced in the ADC model, using a special block. The quantization error is a very important problem in simulation like this, especially so for using a sigma-delta ADC that shapes the frequency spectrum of the quantization noise.

After the values of the input signal samples were determined through the ADC model above described, these were introduced in the ‘Subsystem3’ block (Figure 1), where the active power calculated using the suggested algorithms for processing.

During the simulation check performed in this way, the parameters of the input signals that were the object of the processing had the values defined in Table 1. The values in columns separated by commas correspond to harmonics with different orders. This means that, for example in the column for ls values 1; 0.34; 0.22; 0.17 correspond to l1=1; l3=0.34; l5=0.22; l7=0.17, and so on. In addition, for example, the value of the amplitude of the third harmonic of the current signal is determined as the multiple of the parameters l3=0.34 and IR=10 A, etc. In Table 1, the notation is completely in agreement with Equations (1). The value of active power P is determined based on the definition formula (IEEE Std. 1459-2000, 2000). This value is used with a purpose of evaluating the relative error in calculation of active power P’ by the proposed algorithm, Equation (9).

sec.p: The superposed noise and jitter will, in simulations performed in this way, cause a relative error in detection at the fundamental frequency of 0.001%. Simulations show that the method is susceptible to the presence of noise in the voltage signal, whereas it is immune to the presence of noise in current. The influence of noise is dependent on the sampling frequency. The higher the sampling frequency, the larger the susceptibility to noise obtained, because one of the dummy signal ZCs, which is introduced by added noise, may be detected.

It can be seen (Table 1) that the very simple solution proposed in this paper presents considerable advantages over the highly sophisticated and expensive hardware described in Hindersah et al. (2011) and Martens et al. (2008), where the error in calculation of the observed quantities was no less than ±0.1%. The high level of accuracy in processing AC values is preserved better than in Asquerino et al. (1990), where the calculation was performed within the frequency domain at an error of 0.13%.

sec.title: Experimental verification
sec.p:
In order to verify the results obtained by simulation, experiments were conducted, using a laboratory prototype of a ‘star’ connected induction machine. The control structure is consists of six thyristors, whereas each pair of back-to-back connected thyristors is connected between the phase source voltage and the appropriate phase of the induction machine, in a ‘star’ connection. The experimental set-up consists of voltage and current transducers, a connector block, data acquisition card and processing computer (PC). An acquisition card NI ELVIS/PCI-6251 Bundle (National Instruments) is used to input the current and voltage signals at each phase in the PC, where they are subjected to the proposed algorithm for processing. LEM HTR current and LEM CV3 voltage transducers were used as measurement hardware. The DAQ card sampling rate was 250 kS/s.

For n=1500 rpm (the synchronous speed of the machine), ‘star’ connection, the parameters of current and voltage harmonics in phase ‘a’ were recorded using the existing software (NI LabVIEW) Table 2. The signals with this harmonics content were processed using the proposed algorithm for the calculation of the active power and RMS values of voltage and current. Figure 2 shows the results of measuring performed in this manner, which are considerably better than the procedures that are based on the measuring performed within the frequency domain (Cristaldi et al., 1996), where the measuring error was in the range of 0.2%. During the experimental tests conducted in this manner, parallel measurements of RMS voltage and current were conducted using a highly precise multimeter Fluke 8845 A, all to the purpose of evaluating the possibilities to use the proposed algorithm in the realization of a new multimeter (Fluke, 2012). The difference between the simulation and experimental results are due to the measurement process uncertainty, A/D converter error and transducers errors.

sec.p: Based on the obtained results (Figure 2), it can be concluded that the procedure described in this paper can be used as a sufficiently precise method of determining the active power and RMS values of complex input AC signals. The proposed measuring algorithm can be implemented in the general-purpose microprocessors. Unlike the algorithm (Odzemir and Ferikoglu, 2004) that is based on a complex modification of a DFT algorithm, the former algorithm has a simple structure and can overcome the limitations posed by the processing performed within the frequency domain.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Based on the time-domain analysis of total instantaneous power p(t), it follows that the active power in public distribution networks can be calculated by (9), at the semi-period of the input voltage signal, provided the processed signals possess odd harmonic components. The new method requires fewer computations than the known methods. This is an important difference to be taken into consideration when comparing its implementation in this approach to the processing to the results previously published (Hamid et al., 2002; Hindersah et al., 2011; Martens et al., 2008; Odzemir and Ferikoglu, 2004). The presented algorithm needs no synchronization. The analysis shows that the proposed algorithm remains highly accurate in processing of periodic signals in real environment. The precision limit of the proposed algorithm was investigated theoretically, experimentally and by simulation. The real limit of precision was found experimentally, and it was 0.05% in the laboratory environment.
